This might sound naive, but I believe there could be a more straightforward reason why more distant galaxies seem to be moving away faster.
The further away an astronomical object is, the older the light that arrives is (ie: the light from something four billion lightyears away took four billion years to arrive).
So maybe what we're seeing is how fast they were going when the light from these objects left, not how fast they are going when the light arrives here?
The further away objects would naturally appear to be traveling faster, as when the light we are receiving now was emitted is further into the past and thus closer to the big bang.
The whole "things get faster the further away they are" could be an optical illusion, caused by the speed of light.

Einstein's vacuum energy wasn't the same as the vacuum energy we are talking about.

Einstein proposed this kind of energy as a mechanism by which the Universe could be in a steady state, not expanding nor contracting.  His earlier theories had a problem in that, they predicted that space must either be expanding or contracting, and it could never be something in between.

This was used to support Steady State Theory, which was the original way scientists tried to avoid the "God" question.  Physicists don't like beginnings, because it implies that even physical reality must have had a cause.  If physical reality had a cause, then Naturalism is false, and many scientists subscribe to Naturalism.

Scientists, unable to avoid the prospect of a beginning of time, now try to attack philosophy by saying that quantum mechanics defy the laws of logic, and thus they can say anything they want.

Newton's third law of motion states that every force an object m1 exerts on another object m2 will have a reaction force of the same magnitude exerted on m1 by m2. The universe expanding is not accurately represented by something acting a force on the universe. While we don't know why the universe is expanding, Newton's third law would not apply.

Moreover, the universe is not expanding, space is, as far as we know. Space is not an object which Newton's laws of motion apply to.

I don't think so. Let the galaxy originally move as frame S' with velocity u relative to us, then soon the galaxy is moving with a speed v' relative to S'. From our perspective, sure. Photons appear to be moving through space.

But from the perspective of the photon, what is the length of the path through which it moves?

Observed Length = Rest Length x √(1 - v²/c²)

If v = c, then:

Observed Length = Rest Length x √(1 - 1)
Observed Length = Rest Length x √(0)
Observed Length = Rest Length x 0
Observed Length = 0

From the perspective of the photon, the universe has length 0. It takes 0 time units to travel 0 distance units.

@XIIIXDavidXIIIX The 'great freeze' refers to the fact that as the universe gets larger, the same amount of energy will be spread over a larger area. Since the temperature of an area is the average energy of that area (the amount of energy per unit area), the universe gets colder as it expands. 

However, this does not mean that things will stop moving apart. In fact, matter will be more spread apart, so gravitational forces will be weaker. Thus expansion actually will be faster than today!

@DoctorFastest ...because then things toward the outside of our light cone would be accelerating faster. We could postulate some other sort of force outside the light cone, which doesn't diminish with distance... but this is much less straightforward than the cosmological constant/dark energy idea, so we dismiss it by Occam's Razor. Of course, it *could* turn out to be something weird that doesn't fit in well with our other theories, but that's not where we would *start* looking.

@xitsKittox We don't know that yet. If the universe *does* keep growing, which a lot of people think, then yeah, all the stars will die out. Stars all die eventually as they run out of fuel and radiate away their remaining heat. No new stars will form because matter will be too spread out. And everything will get very cold as the same amount of energy gets spread out over a larger area. 

That's only one possibility though. People are still working on figuring this out.

@XIIIXDavidXIIIX It's true that some stars are dying and some are being born. However, the idea is that as the universe gets spread out enough, new stars will no longer be able to form. There will eventually not be enough dust in any one place! 

So no more new stars, just dust (as the old stars eventually die). The dust gets sparser as it spreads out. It also gets colder - the temperature of an area is its average energy, so as the same amount of energy is spread out over a larger area...cold!

@SoYeahImConnor Like an explosion. Rings are in two dimensions - things move away to the side, but not up and down. But matter on a large scale is moving apart in *every* direction, like an explosion. 

And it's cool to realize that it's moving away like an explosion from *every* fixed point. Pick any fixed point, and matter on a large scale is moving away from it like an explosion! (As Sean explained, we know that because the further away the thing you look at, the faster it is moving away!)
